Issues.Title: ng_package may generate imports to external packages bypassing the globals config
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package `@angular/bazel` ### Description `@Injectable`s compiled using `ng_package` may contain generated imports referencing external libraries. Normally external libraries would be put in the `ng_package` `globals` so they are not included in the package, but the generated imports might unexpectedly reference sub-paths of those libraries not listed in `globals`. This could a) cause external things to be included in the package b) cause a compilation error if any components are referenced by those generated imports because the `ngfactory` files are excluded (see below or repro) ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/jbedard/ng_package-material, specifically https://github.com/jbedard/ng_package-material/commit/6dbe9da746f463a8e519272c5d4e8c2a9e8dba99 ## üî• Exception or Error ``` [!] (Plugin at position 3 plugin) Error: Could not resolve import '@angular/cdk/scrolling/virtual-scroll-viewport.ngfactory' from '...long tmp dir path.../bazel-out/darwin-fastbuild/bin//npm.es6/external/angular_material/src/cdk/overlay/overlay-container.js' ``` ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 
7.1
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ng_package may generate imports to external packages bypassing the globals config" (#28991)

Issues.Title: ci: remove dev-infra as owner on material-ci folder
Issues.Body:
Currently, whenever someone on fw-core approvals list approves a change
to the angular_material_blocklist.js file, it is not sufficient because
dev-infra is also requested as a mandatory reviewer. This does not make
sense because this folder only contains the list of ignored tests and
not anything dev-infra related.

Previously, we tried to fix this by creating a "Material CI" section
underneath the existing "Build & CI" section, so that the "Material CI"
rule would override the rule matching the entire "tools" folder.
Unfortunately, this did not work. This commit attempts to resolve the
problem by explicitly marking all sub-folders in the "tools" folder
as owned by dev-infra (leaving out "material-ci"), so "material-ci"
is only referenced by the rule assigning fw-core as code owners.

Note: If anyone knows a better way to fix this, let me know. This is 
the only thing I could think of.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "ci: remove dev-infra as owner on material-ci folder" (#28990)

Issues.Title: feat(core): update schematic to migrate to explicit query timing
Issues.Body:
Introduces an update schematic for the `@angular/core` package that
automatically migrates pre-V8 `ViewChild` and `ContentChild` queries to
the new explicit timing syntax. This is not required yet, but with Ivy, queries
will be "dynamic" by default. Therefore specifying an explicit query timing
ensures that developers can smoothly migrate to Ivy (once it's the default).

Read more about the explicit timing API here: https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/28810
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(core): update schematic to migrate to explicit query timing" (#28983)

Issues.Title: fix(compiler): fix handling of escaped characters in the lexer
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [x] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?

Issue Number: #28843

Previously the start of a character indicated by an escape sequence
was being incorrectly computed by the lexer, which caused tokens
to include the start of the escaped character sequence in the
preceding token. In particular this affected the name extracted
from opening tags if the name was terminated by an escape sequence.
For example, `<t\n>` would have the name `t\` rather than `t`.

## What is the new behavior?

This fix refactors the lexer to use a "cursor" object to iterate over
the characters in the template source. There are two cursor implementations,
one expects a simple string, the other expects a string that contains
JavaScript escape sequences that need to be unescaped.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information

Alternative to #28844
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(compiler): fix handling of escaped characters in the lexer " (#28978)

Issues.Title: Have a "global" component registry of all entry components.
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Description

In order to render dynamic components we will somehow need to get hold of the `component-TYPE` at some point.

Let's imagine a situation where the "backend" tells us what component should be rendered in form of a returned `string` value.

Somehow this `string` need to be resolved into a `component-TYPE`.

Solutions on SO suggest creating a map, something like the following:

```
const classesMap = {
  "AComponentString": AComponentType,
  "BComponentString": BComponentType
}
```
here are a couple SO solutions: 
[SO1](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49168240/angular-5-instantiate-a-component-from-its-name-as-a-string)
[SO2](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40222579/angular-2-resolve-component-factory-with-a-string)
[SO3](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40115072/how-to-load-component-dynamically-using-component-name-in-angular2)

When a more dynamic general approach is chosen and we loop through the factories which are declared private, things are about to become very adventurous.

In order to use dynamic components effectively throughout our apps, we need a reliable and complete stringComponent-MAP. This MAP should be updated/completed  when lazy modules with entryComponents are loaded.

### Describe the solution you'd like

So my suggestion is to use [entryComponents](https://angular.io/api/core/NgModule#entryComponents) directly to create such a `MAP`.

something like this could be possible:

```
@NgModule({
...
   entryComponents: [{"AComponentString": AComponentType}, {"BComponentString": BComponentType}, OtherComponentTypeThatWillNotBeAddedToTheMAP]
 ...
})
```

maybe through a decorator?

```
@NgModule({
...
   entryComponents: [@add2Map('AComponentString') AComponentType, @add2Map('BComponentString') BComponentType, OtherComponentTypeThatWillNotBeAddedToTheMAP]
 ...
})
```
Maybe the `MAP` could be accessible through a `StringComponentResolver` class that is somewhat analogous to `ComponentFactoryResolver`.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

+ Creating a MAP by hand feels very unsatisfying.
+ Creating a MAP by looping through private properties feels like not a longterm and save solution.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Have a "global" component registry of all entry components." (#28977)

## What is the current behavior?

Currently the only method to manually set errors is `setErrors`. Adding or removing a specific error could be simplified using the new methods introduced:

```typescript
const loginCtrl = new FormControl();
loginCtrl.setErrors({'notUnique': true});
```

## What is the new behavior?

```typescript
const loginCtrl = new FormControl();
loginCtrl.addError('notUnique', true);
loginCtrl.removeError('tooComplicated');
```

Issues.Title: ng_package only marks main @angular packages as external
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
`@angular/bazel`

### Description
Currently `ng_package` [hardcodes a list](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/8.0.0-beta.5/packages/bazel/src/ng_package/ng_package.bzl#L61-L95) of external packages to not include in the package being built. This list is a little arbitrary making it hard to tell when this must be done manually or if `ng_package` does it for you etc. It should probably either do nothing or be replaced with something more generic such as anything in `node_modules` or `dependencies` from `package.json`.

The error message is also quite cryptic and appears to be very angular/component specific. For example when depending on `@angular/material/x` I got an error about an ngfactory file file missing from an indirect dependency:
```
[!] (Plugin at position 3 plugin) Error: Could not resolve import '@angular/cdk/scrolling/virtual-scroll-viewport.ngfactory' from '...long tmp dir path.../bazel-out/darwin-fastbuild/bin/<path>/npm.es6/external/angular_material/src/cdk/overlay/overlay-container.js'
```

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
A basic repro showing the issue when depending on material: https://github.com/jbedard/ng_package-material, running `bazel build //ui:npm` produces the error.

In this case it can be fixed quite easily by just adding:
```
   globals = {
       '@angular/material/button': 'ng.material.button',
       '@angular/material/icon': 'ng.material.icon',
   }
```
But that doesn't seem obvious based on the error message, and isn't clear why this one is required but something such as `@angular/animations` is not required.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ng_package only marks main @angular packages as external" (#28971)

### Command


### Description

My application has a couple of settings that are perfectly secure within the context of their use, but which produce (certainly helpful) warnings.  I've configured my app this way intentionally, and I don't want to see these warnings every time I start my application for development.

Here is my command:

    ng serve --host 0.0.0.0 --port 8000 --ssl true --ssl-key localhost.key --ssl-cert localhost.cert

And the warnings:

```
WARNING: This is a simple server for use in testing or debugging Angular applications
locally. It hasn't been reviewed for security issues.

Binding this server to an open connection can result in compromising your application or
computer. Using a different host than the one passed to the "--host" flag might result in
websocket connection issues. You might need to use "--disableHostCheck" if that's the
case.
```

The top one is useful, but I don't need to be reminded, I'm already not using Angular CLI in production.

The second one is of course useful as well, but I'm running this app inside of a Docker container on my dev machine with an port exposed to the host, so that's not an issue in my case either.

### Describe the solution you'd like
A broad flag (or a number of more specific flags) to disable warnings at start time.  I have found another issue requesting something like this here:

https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/11802

However, the answer given to this is to redirect stderr.  This does have the desired effect, but it _also_ disables all compile-time errors, which I _need_ for the development process.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Either find a configuration that Angular complains about less, or simply ignore the warnings.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Disable start-up warnings" (#13765)

Issues.Title: ng new my-app does not have css per QuickStart Guide
Issues.Body:
Following the new app tutorial https://angular.io/guide/quickstart

Haven't used Angular since Version 4.

When you create a new application exactly per the instructions, there is NO CSS AT ALL.  When you start the development server, no CSS file is even loaded or compiled.

CSS is an absolute must-have for any web application in 2019.  This is a critical issue.  Should we just use react?

To be clear, there is an app.component.scss file but nothing you place in it is used or compiled.

I think it's absolutely reasonable that a new application has working CSS.  It really sets the bar low for the current status of this project.

Issues.Title: Running 3rd party schematics should be possible using both <collection>:<schematics> and --collection <collection> syntax
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ X] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Hard to say ### Description Following the upcoming Angular Schematics guide there seems to be an issue with the support for `--collection` flag when trying to specify 3rd party schematics collection in `ng generate`. The command `ng generate my-schematic-name --collection collection-name` should be equivalent to `ng generate collection-name:schematics-name` but only the second works in my case. To be more specific, I can run `ng g @angular-extensions/model:model feature/user` but if I try to run `ng g model feature/user --collection @angular-extensions/model` then it fails as it doesn't recognize the passed collection and the `@schematics/angular` doesn't contain any `model`... Any ideas why that could be? I am working on the windows machine ( with cygwin ) could it be paths or ? ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. `ng add @angular-extensions.model` (or any other 3rd party library which contains schematics, eg: `@angular/material` or `@ngrx/store`) 2. `ng generate model examples/user --collection @angular-extensions/model` This results in a error where `model` schematics is not found in the `@schematics/angular` which is a default collection in Angular CLI so that means the `--collection` was ignored. On the other hand, everything works just fine when using `ng generate @angular-extensions/model:model examples/user`. ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: Add no-output-named-after-standard-event to tslint.json
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

### Command
- [X] new

### Description
There is a rule `no-output-named-after-standard-event` in codelyzer, I think it should be enabled as a default setting because we can not remember ALL the native event name. 

When we use the standard event name, that could be easily causing an unexpected problem. 

So I recommend to enable it when we just start a new project.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Add `"no-output-named-after-standard-event": true` to `tslint.json` as default when using `ng new` to create a new Angular project.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add no-output-named-after-standard-event to tslint.json" (#13750)

Issues.Title: Angular 7/Webpack/Karma Typescript compilation error
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ x] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? No ### Description I¬¥m configuring a Hybrid application to work with Karma unit test. I see a nonsense error that is not clear why it is happening and cause the Karma-webpack bundle failure. If you remove the file from the `files` property in karma.config.js the webpack bundle will be compiled successfully. As you can see the `test.ts` is defined in `tsconfig.spec.json` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Build an angular application with these configurations manually: **webpack.config.js** ``` .... { test: /\.ts$/, parser: { system: true }, exclude: path.resolve(__dirname, "node_modules"), use: [{ loader: '@ngtools/webpack' }, { loader: 'tslint-loader', options: { failOnHint: true } }] }, .... new AngularCompilerPlugin({ mainPath: path.resolve('./app/main.ts'), tsConfigPath: ifTest(path.resolve('src/tsconfig.spec.json'), path.resolve('src/tsconfig.app.json')), entryModule: 'src/app/app.module#AppModule', sourceMap: true, nameLazyFiles: true, hostReplacementPaths: ifProd({ [path.resolve('src/environments/environment.ts')]: path.resolve('src/environments/environment.prod.ts')}) }), ``` **test.ts** ``` // This file is required by karma.conf.js and loads recursively all the .spec and framework files import 'zone.js'; import 'zone.js/dist/zone-testing'; import 'zone.js/dist/long-stack-trace-zone'; // import 'zone.js/dist/proxy.js' import 'zone.js/dist/sync-test'; // import 'zone.js/dist/jasmine-patch' // import 'zone.js/dist/async-test' // import 'zone.js/dist/fake-async-test' declare const require: any; declare const __karma__: any; console.log('pass from here'); __karma__.loaded = function () {}; // First, initialize the Angular testing environment. setTimeout(() => { debugger; // Then we find all the tests. const context = require.context('./app', true, /\.spec\.ts$/); console.log(context); // And load the modules. context.keys().map(context); // and run the tests. __karma__.start(); }, 10000); ``` karma.config.js ``` module.exports = function (config) { config.set({ basePath: '', frameworks: ['jasmine'], plugins: [ require('karma-jasmine'), require('karma-chrome-launcher'), require('karma-jasmine-html-reporter'), require('karma-coverage-istanbul-reporter'), require('karma-webpack'), require('ts-loader') ], files: [ { pattern: './test.ts', watched: false }, ], preprocessors: { './test.ts': ['webpack'] }, webpack: require('../webpack.config')({env: 'test'}), webpackMiddleware: { stats: 'errors-only', //logLevel: "error" }, client: { clearContext: false // leave Jasmine Spec Runner output visible in browser }, coverageIstanbulReporter: { dir: require('path').join(__dirname, '../coverage'), reports: ['html', 'lcovonly', 'text-summary'], fixWebpackSourcePaths: true }, mime: { "text/x-typescript": ["ts"] }, reporters: ['progress', 'kjhtml'], port: 9876, colors: true, logLevel: config.LOG_INFO, autoWatch: true, browsers: ['ChromeHeadless'], singleRun: false }); }; ``` **src/ts.spec.json** ``` { "extends": "../tsconfig.json", "compilerOptions": { "outDir": "../out-tsc/spec", "types": [ "jasmine", "node" ] }, "files": [ "test.ts", "polyfills.ts", "../app/main.ts" ], "include": [ "**/*.spec.ts", "**/*.d.ts" ] } ``` ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: CdkDropListGroupDisabled Blocking Native Interactions
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?

That `cdkDropListGroupDisabled` directive disabled all the `cdkDrag` components but kept the scrolling behaviour.

#### What is the current behavior?

Native Input not working when using `cdkDropListGroupDisabled`. The disabled effect works, because you can't drag any cdkDrag component. 

Looking at the source code I found that this happened in this function:
https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/740a2eeaa921c201c21b7a0fee980cf05ad7c2aa/src/cdk/drag-drop/drag-ref.ts#L965-L976

Which will call this function:

https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/740a2eeaa921c201c21b7a0fee980cf05ad7c2aa/src/cdk/drag-drop/drag-styling.ts#L47-L59

It adds to the style of the component `touch-action: none` when the enabled parameter is false.

Then I looked why it passed false when the disabled variable should be true.

https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/740a2eeaa921c201c21b7a0fee980cf05ad7c2aa/src/cdk/drag-drop/drag-ref.ts#L216-L223

This should get called when disabled and it actually isn't (I placed a breakpoint there).

Then I tested using `cdkDragDisabled` insted of `cdkDropListGroupDisabled` and the setter disable was called and everything worked correctly.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

Create a `cdkDropListGroup` and disable it.


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

Angular Material 7.3.3, Angular CDK 7.3.3
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "CdkDropListGroupDisabled Blocking Native Interactions" (#15319)

Issues.Title: refactor(button): use [attr.disabled] host binding in MatButton
Issues.Body:
With ivy, MatAnchor will inherit the host bindings of MatButton. The
`[disabled]` binding would then be an error since HTMLAnchorElement does
not have a `disabled` property. To work around this, we can simply use
the `disabled` attribute instead, which will always be reflected back
into the property when it exists.

Also add a missing `fixture.detectChanges()` to a test.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(button): use [attr.disabled] host binding in MatButton" (#15308)

Issues.Title: Refactor RxJS code to not explicitly set generics
Issues.Body:
There are several instances in material where we are setting the generic type of an RxJS function explicitly in order to get a desired outcome. It would be better to cast instead. (Ideally, you don't have to do either, so what I'm talking about here is when you *must* do something explicit to get the return type to be correct)

For example:

```ts
defer<Foo>(() => someObservable)
```

should be:

```ts
defer(() => someObservable) as Observable<Foo>
```
This is because RxJS changes how generics are ordered for some functions between version 6.3 and 6.4.

It may even be worth testing these changes against updating to 6.4.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Refactor RxJS code to not explicitly set generics" (#15307)

Issues.Title: fix(schematics): incorrectly throws if NgModule uses namespaced decorator
Issues.Body:
Currently if the developer defines the primary app `NgModule` using a namespaced
import (e.g. `@ngCore.NgModule`), the Material schematics will incorrectly not detect
that module as the logic that resolves the decorator name of a class declaration
is flawed.

This is because it incorrectly traverses a `PropertyAccessExpression`, while the
accessed property name is exposed at the root level `PropertyAccessExpression`.

This PR fixes this and also adds additional unit tests for the `hasNgModuleImport`
utility function. (We have integration tests for this; but we don't test that special case)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(schematics): incorrectly throws if NgModule uses namespaced decorator" (#15298)
